prompt: What are some mixed reviews about the book?
completion: I bought Masala Lab because its blurb sounded interesting. And because it had excellent reviews. Now, a disclaimer  - I'm definitely not the target audience for this book. I've been cooking for more years than I care to remember. I grew up in the school of, When I said one handful, I meant the size of my hand!, or recipes from relatives that asked for 'a pinch of this, a dash of that'. I learnt the basics from my mother and from poring over recipes in magazines. I learnt quickly to adapt to not having a certain ingredient or substituting something else for it. But, as I said, the blurb seemed interesting, and I'm always curious to know the whys and wherefores.First, the positives. Krish Ashok's book is a nerd's foray into the science of cooking - he talks of how heat affects carbohydrates, proteins and fats differently; what a Maillard reaction is and its effect in cooking; why powdered spices should be made/bought in small quantities; how to layer acids to add taste and why they are important, and so on. Split into different chapters, he examines the science  - the physics, chemistry and even biology  - that goes into the products, processes and techniques of Indian cooking. He dissects various 'common' spices such as garam masala, provides a generalised idea of common gravies (much like a restaurant) and suggests how to mimic several regional cuisines using ingredients that are unique to those cuisines. Flow charts and illustrations make the information easier to understand.He also gives you a general idea of the different ways of cooking  - pressure cooking, stove-top and oven; the best way to go about making and freezing different types of gravies (that you can then customize to individual dishes); the different spice blends, and how to use them to good effect. So, experienced as I am, I'm more than glad to incorporate some of the information into my cooking to see how it will go.I also agree with him that the term 'authentic' for a certain dish is redundant, especially in the Indian context where the same dish appears in many regional cuisines with their own localised variations  - and they are all authentic. Yet, I must confess that I'd rather get an 'authentic' recipe that closely mimics the traditional way in which it was made than a modern version which completely changes everything. Now, what irked me about the book? Plenty. First, the condescension that dripped off the page in the 'Just kidding' kind of way. Calling people who do something differently from you 'Idiots' is not the best way to go about imparting information. Suggesting that if someone does something differently  - especially when it is not even clear that anyone following your instructions is going to be successful  - they are merely wasting their time at best or are downright moronic at worst is beyond condescending; that devolves into, My, what a big ego he has! territory. Secondly, while I agree that having some gravies frozen on hand to adapt to various dishes is a godsend when you are beginning your journey as a cook, the whole point of home cooking is the freshness and the variety you bring to the dishes - with the different spices, techniques, processes. What's the point if by following Ashok's algorithms, you turn your dishes into the same mass-produced generic 'curry'? What's with the condescension towards food bloggers (other than Bongeats, which he seems to approve of) or recipes on the Internet? Good food bloggers not only give you a recipe, but also offer substitutions, tips based on their experience, and simplified versions of doing things. They have tested their recipes many times and made it as fool-proof as possible. Why not take advantage of their experience? The repeated 'jokes'! Ashok is like that annoying old 'uncle-ji' he references, who corners you at every family gathering to tell you the same ghisa-pita joke. Which, being polite, you must laugh at, even if it was not remotely funny the first time! His sense of humour punches down and I suppose he thinks he's being humorous. He's just being tiresome. My final conclusion is  - Masala Lab has some very good information. But it is badly written, has cringe-worthy humour, and is over-hyped. Buy this book, even if you are a beginner, only if you want to understand the science behind some of the techniques. Because cooking is not just science, it is also an art. It is the joy of creating a dish, not manufacturing a product. I'm sure there are some excellent cookbooks for beginners out there which make cooking a joy and a journey of discovery. (And doesn't treat you like an idiot for wanting to do something differently.) Find some!

prompt: How heat works to cook food, how proteins and carbohydrates and fats are affected by heat, acid, sugar, salt, etc. Why you shouldn't store powdered spices for months altogether, and why Coke is absolutely the wrong choice to counteract a massive dose of chillies
completion: In the first few chapters of Masala Lab, Krish Ashok focuses on the physics, chemistry and some of the biology that goes into the ingredients, utensils, processes and techniques of the average Indian kitchen. He examines common flavours and what they consist of, how they work, and so on. In the last section of the book, Ashok suggests algorithms to make individualized rice, bread, gravy, chutney/raita and salad dishes, based on several different regional cuisines. The best thing about Ashok's writing is that he is good at explaining science in layman's terms. He knows how much explanation is needed, and how much would be too much: he strikes the balance well. The many illustrations to explain concepts are a bonus. That said, while the writing tries to be witty, it does go overboard at times and becomes irritating. Earlier this year, I had read Harold McGee's definitive tome on food science, On Food and Cooking. Having read that, I was a little sceptical if Ashok's book, only about a quarter of the length of McGee's, would be as impactful. While the books do cover some of the same ground, their goals are separate. McGee sets out to cover food science in its entirety (he even examines, for each ingredient group, nutritive values, history, manufacturing, spoilage and contamination); he is thorough. Ashok's book, on the other hand, has a relatively narrow focus: just a few major Indian cuisines, and just enough knowledge imparted to help an Indian home cook understand the how, why, what and when of Indian food. That said, I was not really the target audience for this book. I have been cooking for the past thirty years and more; I studied hotel management, so do have some food production training. And, given that I cook three meals a day without any domestic help, I simply don't have the time to do any of the experiments Ashok suggests. What's more, I realize a lot of what the 'average Indian' seems to do—pressure cook by the 'whistle system'; pressure-cook rice, mostly cook Indian food, adore chillies, etc—is not me. At all. But yes, I did learn some things that I will be implementing in my cooking. And I can imagine that anybody who likes cooking but is worried about following recipes, or is new to cooking, might benefit a good deal from this book.

completion: feel sad and harsh for rating this 3 stars. Because it deserves more than just 'liked it'. The book has an interesting mandate, and I had totally bought into it. completion: A funny, witty and good book for all food science enthusiasts and aspiring chefs. The author has clearly done extensive research of Indian cuisine and presented in the best form. He has even experimented some north and south Indian cuisine to understand the importance of flavours, spices, and different regional oils. The book is easy to read. filled with details and more importantly some interesting recipes. One thing I learnt from this book there is no authentic Indian food and the author explains it.

prompt: Are there any diagrams and charts in the books?
completion: This book described a fun, scientific proof driven approach to cooking and included detailed charts and diagrams to neatly summarise each concept that was being explained. Not shying away from debunking age old myths and stereotypes practised in the kitchen, this book has many suggestions and tips that might seem egregious at first but upon reading the science driven cases made for them, will help readers become more efficient and effective cooks.

prompt: What's your favorite line in the book?
completion: My favourite line in the book is when the author describes biriyani as 'rice and life nourishing protein being brought together like two companies merging and unlike two families at an arranged marriage'

prompt: When there are multiple ways to skin a cat, why should cooking be any different?
completion: There are fundamentally two approaches to mastering cooking- the art of cooking, and, the science of cooking. The sublime art of cooking emphasizes instinct, intuition and ingenuity to hone the culinary craft. The science of cooking recommends mastery through understanding and application of cooking techniques. Most Indian women, including my mother, are expert practitioners of the art of cooking. They have a natural flair for rustling up marvels in the kitchen by adding a little bit of this and that till the taste is just right. But for the unfortunate few like me not blessed with the natural flair that this approach demands, the Masala Lab by Krish Ashok is a godsend. It demystifies Indian cooking by explaining in simple language the chemistry, physics and biology behind the culinary process. It covers properties of commonly used ingredients, building of flavors using spice combinations, common food pairings, various cooking techniques, and efficient method of using cooking appliances. The author has also included cheat-sheets and algorithms for easy understanding and quick recreation of popular Indian dishes. There are authors who have attempted to unravel the secrets of Western cooking, but Krish Ashok is the first one to scientifically deconstruct Indian cooking! This book has been long overdue. Recommended for bachelors, novice cooks, daughters intimidated by their mother's natural flair for cooking, and experienced cooks seeking to uncover the secret behind culinary magic (the book is guaranteed to provide an 'Eureka' moment or two)!!

prompt: Is this a booking primer?
completion: I was so engrossed in reading the book, that I managed to burn the first meal I attempted after I started reading the book, but despite the charring, the balance of flavours worked. A book which is going to be my cooking primer going forward. Four stars instead of five, because of the subpar editing, and the frequent repetitions. Like many other books written and released during the pandemic, a little more time should have been spent post writing to make the book tighter than it is. It is also a book that may not appeal to the person who cooks three meals a day- they just do not have the time to indulge in all that experimentation.

prompt: Does this book delve into the gastronomy?
completion: Delving into the gastronomic world through a scientific lens, Krish Ashok's 'Masala Lab: The Science of Indian Cooking' is a culinary odyssey that captures the essence of both tradition and innovation. As an avid reader, author, and discerning critic, I find myself intrigued by this intriguing exploration that seeks to unravel the secrets behind the aromas, flavors, and techniques that define Indian cuisine.

prompt: How is the author's writing style?
completion: Ashok's writing style is an artful balance between informative and approachable. He adeptly navigates complex scientific concepts, making them accessible to readers of diverse backgrounds. The engaging narrative captures the essence of Ashok's passion for both science and cooking.

prompt: How is the book structured?
completion: The structure is simple and easy to follow. It is bottom-up which means you start of by knowing about the most basic things like heat and temperature and work your way up to Biryani. Each section describes the fundamental set of principles from chemistry or physics that explain why ingredients behave the way they do, how to use and combine them, and how their properties can be leveraged to create your dish.

prompt: How did you find the tone of the book?
completion: The tone of the book was a pain point for me. Attempts of dry humour, oversimplified reductions, and unnecessary detours took away from the experience rather than adding to it. And like most non-fiction books, it can be an information overload and would be better assimilated over a period of reading and re-reading and trying and taking deeper dives through other information sources.

prompt: How is author's writing style?
completion: The book is quirky, and funny and the writing style is more like a conversation that you are having. This book offers tips, tricks and recipes, to elevate your cooking skills and also how to prevent yourself from bawling your eyes out while chopping those pesky onions and which part of the vegetable you should use for optimum flavour. It also has the explanation s to why your mom's and grandmothers tips and tricks work. In short, I loved it. I think beginners and experts in the kitchen will enjoy the book alike and pick something useful for yourself. It does have something for everyone and explanations of why they are the way they are.

prompt: What would you say about this book?
completion: As a reader of Krish Ashok's blog, his music, memes, articles, cooking videos and of course, his twitter account; it was but obvious that I would buy this book. So of course, I pre-ordered on the day it came out. I read through this faster than I do most thrillers. (not the ideal way for sure - but I'm certainly going to make notes when I try to implement some of the recommendations and suggestions in this.) As Ashok mentions in his book, the first half is around cooking tips and tricks that many experienced cooks may be aware of, even if they don't really understand the science of why it is the way it is. Very fascinating. The second half deals with a lot of misconceptions and plain falseties that people educated by whatsapp forwards believe in. (stuff like Msg or baking powder being bad for you). Through all this there are some great tips on everything from the basics (how to cook rice well, how to mix dough for roties well, how to brine, how to make a good salad) to (and this is more important) how to use this understanding of food science to ignore/forget all the nonsensical recipes that you may have tried to memorize/follow in vain and instead, like an engineer, build a series of easy to remember, follow algorithms to make cooking an easier, more successful craft. So inspired was I that I immediately set about making some home made curd and later tried to use the measurements from the cook to make better roties. A must read.

prompt: How did this book change my thinking about cooking?
completion: There is not a lot of times when I say this but 'This Book Changed My Life'. This book changed how I know Cooking and Science. If I have to put it in simple words then this book is a masterpiece of knowing the mere essentials of Indian cooking, with the spiciness of Science that will leave you charmed at times.

prompt: How is author's writing scheme?
completion: The writing scheme of Krish Ashok Sir is brilliant, he has used humour to enlighten us with the enormous knowledge he has about cooking. From the first page onwards you will be hooked to know and read more and more about the Science we needed to learn in our school. And being honest I hated chemistry my entire life for all the right things it comprises of but this book changed how I know Chemistry and yeah Physics too!!

prompt: How does this book compare with other cook books?
completion: Majority of the CookBooks focus on HowTo (cooking) but this one centres around WHYs of cooking. Not for everyone but very good read for the ones who are looking for science behind cooking, mostly indian cooking methods.

prompt: What are some cooking tricks mentioned in this book?
completion: Reasons behind some of the cooking tricks are also mentioned - like why the Tea bag is added along with baking Soda when boiling chickpeas, Why to Sauté/Fry Onions earlier and add Garlic later, why to turn down the stove flame when pressure cooker whistles for first time, why to use low heat when cooking meat or eggs and many more. Food substitutes are also expalined in detail like when to substitute Dahi for Lemon, Tamarind etc, which Fat (Oil) to be used for deep fry and which to be use for light sautéing.

prompt: Do you find this book relatable?
completion: This book is so relatable and relevant for the current times where many have taken on home cooking during the lockdown. The author has smartly explained cooking through scientific terms that would attract the current generation who question for logic and reasoning behind everything. The mindset is definitely different from what our mothers and grand-mothers have been used to - which is quantities by approximation. It's interesting to see concepts like A/B testing, measurements, chemical engineering etc., being applied in the kitchen.

prompt: Is the book technical?
completion: There’s a great bit of technical detail on various aspects of cooking. While not all of that needs to be fed into our brain, it helps visualise and take the meta point instead. He delves into techniques and gives easily followed instructions for a wide range of dishes. Should appreciate the way he listed the table of contents that makes it easy for a quick reference.

prompt: Can techniques mentioned in the book be applied to all cuisines?
completion: A brilliant gateway text for understanding the basics of food science. A lot of these principles can be applied to many cuisines around the world. The author's pragmatic approach to Indian food is infectious thanks to his well-explained reasons, my favourite being the idea that fighting over authenticity of a dish is a silly concept. The absorption of ideas like this one and many others will involve unlearning a few that most of us have grown up with, but it will not be an exercise in futility. Oh, and a special mention to how hilarious Krish Ashok is. He makes this fun and how!

There's also a repetition of some things throughout the book that should have been done away with. But overall, I learnt a lot of things that I can use to my advantage in the kitchen.

prompt: How is author's writing style?
completion: Content is amazing! The writing style is terrible, so condescending and judgemental! Was difficult to get through it but the cooking science and techniques are eye opening.

prompt: Who is this book for?

prompt: Is this book a disappointment?
completion: The science of Indian cooking is an alluring topic and I jumped and bought Krish Ashok's book the moment I saw it. It was a disappointment. The book is full of scientific facts that don't help me understand what happens when we cook foor. I don't want so much science. But I do want to know the science behind the common mistakes that happen in cooking, I do want to know the best way of doing things and the science behind them, and I would love cooking tips. I would like to know why our grandmothers recommended we do things in a certain way, and not in other ways, and why things go wrong sometimes. But what the book offers is a lot of hard science. I am guessing that most ordinary cooks like me will find the book disappointing. I hardly gained anything from it, and I am so interested in kitchen science.
